#Text=Jo 's Will

#Text=As Allan Woodcourt and Jo proceed along the streets where the high church spires and the distances are so near and clear in the morning light that the city itself seems renewed by rest , Allan revolves in his mind how and where he shall bestow his companion .
#Text=" It surely is a strange fact , " he considers , " that in the heart of a civilized world this creature in human form should be more difficult to dispose of than an unowned dog . "
#Text=But it is none the less a fact because of its strangeness , and the difficulty remains .
#Text=At first he looks behind him often to assure himself that Jo is still really following .

#Text=But look where he will , he still beholds him close to the opposite houses , making his way with his wary hand from brick to brick and from door to door , and often , as he creeps along , glancing over at him watchfully .
#Text=Soon satisfied that the last thing in his thoughts is to give him the slip , Allan goes on , considering with a less divided attention what he shall do .
#Text=A breakfast-stall at a street-corner suggests the first thing to be done .
#Text=He stops there , looks round , and beckons Jo .

#Text=Jo crosses and comes halting and shuffling up , slowly scooping the knuckles of his right hand round and round in the hollowed palm of his left , kneading dirt with a natural pestle and mortar .

#Text=What is a dainty repast to Jo is then set before him , and he begins to gulp the coffee and to gnaw the bread and butter , looking anxiously about him in all directions as he eats and drinks , like a scared animal .
#Text=But he is so sick and miserable that even hunger has abandoned him .
#Text=" I thought I was amost a-starvin , sir , " says Jo , soon putting down his food , " but I do n't know nothink -- not even that .

#Text=And Jo stands shivering and looking at the breakfast wonderingly .

#Text= Draw breath , Jo ! "

column1: #Text=" It draws , " says Jo , " as heavy as a cart . "
#Text=He might add , " And rattles like it , " but he only mutters , " I 'm a-moving on , sir . "
#Text=Allan looks about for an apothecary 's shop .
#Text=There is none at hand , but a tavern does as well or better .
#Text=He obtains a little measure of wine and gives the lad a portion of it very carefully .
#Text=He begins to revive almost as soon as it passes his lips .
#Text=" We may repeat that dose , Jo , " observes Allan after watching him with his attentive face .
#Text=" So !

#Text=Now we will take five minutes ' rest , and then go on again .

column1: #Text=" My meritorious , distinguished , honourable officer ! "
#Text=She uses some odd expressions , but is as cordial and full of heart as sanity itself can be -- more so than it often is .
#Text=Allan , very patient with her , waits until she has no more raptures to express , then points out Jo , trembling in a doorway , and tells her how he comes there .
#Text=" Where can I lodge him hereabouts for the present ?
